I'm a big fan of all Half-Life games, but this version has a lot of bugs.  I even experienced a bug at the end of the game after killing the final boss. Furthermore, the graphical improvement is not what I expected. If you have never played Half-Life 1, I recommend the original version.

Saludos, otro juego terminado. DURACIÓN: 11 HORAS EN NORMAL -- Nota 10/10 (El juego es del año 1998, se llama source por una actualizacion de motor, pero su diseño es del 98) (así que preparate a morir muchas veces este es un shooter viejo lineal, de saltar plataformas como loco) es una obra de arte si, 

++++++++ Lo bueno ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++



+++++++ variedad de armas. 

++++ historia (un poco cliche para mi gusto pero es buena)

+++++++ movimientos y controles. responde muy bien cosa que es necesario para un juego de un error y mueres.

+++++ muy pocos bugs, solo encontre 2

+++++ salvado rapido y check point. ayudan mucho para este tipo de juego.

++++++++ variedad de enemigos.

+++++ interactuas con el ambiente armas, cañones, vagones de trenes, etc....

+++++ puedes nadar, correr, caminar, etc......

+++++ la ia responde bien, puedes hacer las cosas de 2 modos alo rambo o a lo spinter cell. aunque la mayoría de veces sera a lo rambo.

++++++ diseño de los niveles recuerdan mucho a los de doom 2, duke nukem 3d, shadow warrior (el viejo) solo faltaria el fanservice :P

+++++++ Música y sonidos bastante bien, no es cansona, ni fastidiosa, y varia mucho.

+++++++ la fisica destrucción de objetos cajas, puzzles como arrastra esta caja para que tape el laser y asi explote y haga un agujero en la pared.


++++++ voces y subtitulos totalmente en español.



--------------------------- LO MALO ----------------------------------------------

- realmente un par de bug gráfico que consegui en cierto niveles puntales se deformaba todo, y no podía ver, apesar de que tenía la configuración recomendada, comence a mover las opciones apagar multi nucleo y aero, eso ayudo mucho.

- los puntos de carga de los niveles, aunque por la limitacion de aquella epoca (1998) es normal que tantos poligonos requieran tantos puntos de cargas, pero de resto la acción es fluida.

[h1]Half-Life: Source[/h1]

Muß man noch etwas zu "Half-Life" sagen? Zum großartigen Klassiker, zum Genrekönig seiner Zeit, zum Meilenstein der Spielgeschichte?

Eigentlich nicht, und doch versuche ich es. "Half-Life" ist ein linearer, storygetriebener First-Person-Shooter. Wir sind Gordon Freeman, theoretischer Physiker und Mitarbeiter im Labor für anomale Materie des geheimen Forschungskomplexes Black Mesa. Ein Experiment läuft gehörig schief und ein Portal zu einer anderen Welt wird geöffnet. Die Wesen, die in unsere Welt eindringen sind andersartig und feindlich...

Allein schon der Anfang ist unvergeßlich. Wir werden in einer Art Schwebebahn durch die riesige Forschungsanlage gefahren. Wir schauen uns um, sehen riesige Gänge, andere Mitarbeiter, Sicherheitspersonal, arbeitende Lastenroboter, einen merkwürdigen Mann im dunklen Anzug mit Aktenkoffer. Durchsagen geleiten unseren Weg. Ein Vorratscontainer verliert radioaktive Flüssigkeit. Die Welt um uns lebt, auch ohne uns. Sie ist wahr. Diese etwa fünfminütige Sequenz gehört zu den großen Passagen der Spielegeschichte.

Die Welt, die "Half-Life" (zu deutsch: Halbwertszeit) erschafft ist erstaunlich real, die dadurch erzeugte Atmosphäre herausragend. Und das auch heute noch, auch wenn die Grafik nun klobig und verwaschen wirkt, auch wenn die Sprachausgabe quäkt und die Sprecher manchmal schwach sind. Und dabei vergißt "Half-Life" auch nicht die Ironie, den weisen Blick auf sich selbst, die Reflektion über das eigene Produkt. Soviel Souveränität ist selten.

Neben diesem Wesentlichen funktioniert (fast) alles perfekt. Die Bedienbarkeit ist extrem gut und flüssig, die Waffenauswahl vielseitig, insbesondere die faszinierend designeten Alienwaffen überraschen und das Brecheisen ist schlichtweg legendär. Auch Rätsel- und Jumppassagen sind richtig gut gebaut. 

Überhaupt das Leveldesign. Derart viel Abwechslung vermißt man heute fast in allen AAA-Titeln. Die Stupidität der meisten heutigen Main-Stream-Shooter sind ein deutlicher Rückschritt im Vergleich zu "Half-Life". 

Gibt es auch Negatives? Kaum. Lediglich die letzten Passagen, die Alienwelt, wird, trotzdem das Design klasse ist, gameplaytechnisch merkwürdig und teils auch nervig. 

Die Grafik war 1998 herausragend, die Musik grandios atmosphärisch. Auch der Umfang überzeugt, 10 Stunden und mehr ist man leicht in dieser außergewöhnlichen Welt gefangen.

Die Source-Version von "Half-Life" ist praktisch gleich dem Original. Lediglich ein paar Grafiken wurden wie etwa das Wasser wurden leicht verbessert. Allerdings: dreimal hatte ich Grafikfehler (Tearing), außerdem waren die Ladezeiten im Vergleich zum Original deutlich länger. Ansonsten sind beide Versionen aber deckungsgleich.

Es gebe noch so Vieles zu berichten und zu loben, aber statt weiter diesen Text zu lesen, sollte man es lieber (wieder einmal) spielen und erleben.

[h1]Wertung:[/h1]
10/10 Atmosphäre
10/10 Story
9/10 Grafik
9/10 Sound
9/10 Spielmechanik
8/10 Balancing
10/10 Spielspass
(Wertungen von Klassikern beziehen immer die technischen Möglichkeiten der Zeit mit ein)

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Wer Gordon Freeman nicht kennt, sollte sich nicht Gamer nennen. Allerdings ist diese Source-Version fast deckungsgleich mit dem Original.

[h1][b]9/10 Gesamtwertung

[h1]One of the best [/h1]
Half life 1 source is a port of hl1 to the source engine.
[h1] Pros [/h1]
Half Life
[h1] Cons [/h1]
None 



Note: Buy the valve complete pack for <20$ (on sale), since you get some of the best games ever made for a very big discount.

Die Unterschiede zum "normalen" Half-Life sind nicht sonderlich groß:
- Shader-Effekte (Wasser), die toll aussehen
- Physik (u.a. Ragdoll, wobei man davon in der geschnittenen Version wenig bis nichts mitbekommt, weil die Leichen ausgeblendet werden)

Aufgefallen sind mir Plotstopper gleich zu Beginn des Spiels (Barney wollte mich trotz Anzug nicht weiterlassen); nach einem erneuten Spielstart wurden mir keine Waffen angezeigt.
Außerdem:
- teilweise Hängenbleib-Bugs
- Positionierungs-Bugs von NPCs

An den Texturen hat sich nichts getan, was auch nicht so schlimm ist, weil die "altbackene" Grafik ihren Charme hat und man in das Jahr 1998 versetzt wird.

Grundsätzlich ein super Spiel, aber ich würde euch trotzdem das "originale" Half-Life empfehlen.

If you own or have already played Half-Life 1 I highly discourage buying this game. The graphical improvements are really minor and would only be barely noticeable when making a direct image comparison. If you want to get a true reimagining of this game then I highly recommend Black Mesa. It's too bad they didn't update Half-Life with improved graphics like they did with Half-Life 2.


Edit: Also has a lot of bugs and glitches that Valve still hasn't fixed, some don't really affect the overall experience but some do.

I played this game for the first time almost 20 years after release, yet it was a wonderful experience. Altough it´s sometimes very difficult to figure out, how to progress further or hard to progress, even on easy difficulty and the graphics is obviously...not that great. But overall, Half-Life is the grandfather of modern FPS´s, so everyone interested in games should make it through this classic game and experience what a true FPS looks like. Peace.

Half-Life Source: It's Half-Life 1 with the source engine. HL1 is my most favorite game if all time. I like it better than HL2. I'm really happy they brought it to the source engine. It has some few minor problems. It crashes every once in a while. Sometimes, some graphics don't load. Despite those minor little issues, which happen rarely for me, the game is very nice and plays smoothly. I like playing HL1 on the source engine more than the original. It has better physics and fixes some problems with the original. Worth the money! Has a great, in depth story, awesome guns, great settings, awesome enemies, and the best protagonist of all time, Gordon Freeman.

Pros?
Freeman's mind was filmed in this port. 
All hl1 maps are ported to a newer bsp format, allowing you to load them in gmod/sfm.
Ragdoll physics and a FLASHLIGHT that actually lights things up like a flashlight
My favorite feature is the inclusion of proper water shaders. 

Cons?
Almost two decades of source engine updates have not been kind to this game.
Visual bugs and other garbage that ruins experience, including broken demo support 
(fun fact: earlier versions didnt have this)

Buy it on sale.
one of the best games on pc.

[h1]TL;DR: Just buy the original.  Don't waste your time on this one unless you want it that badly.  Black Mesa is another viable option[/h1]

So!  Half-Life: Source.  Valve's attempt at porting the original Half-Life from the old GoldSrc engine to the newer Source engine.  A lot of the reviews I had read said it was basically the same old Half-Life with some slightly new physics, ragdolls spawned on an NPC's death, and better lighting and water.  I was expecting almost the [i]exact[/i] same as Half-Life, but there were a few differences here and there.  Also, there's almost no mod support, unlike Half-Life.  Still being an older game, I was able to crank up graphical settings to get maximum enjoyment.

[h1]Better Lighting[/h1]
This is what I was most pleased by.  The original Half-Life had static lighting.  It was just a bubble of light placed in the map, and it changed the brightness of that area.  In Half-Life: Source, however, the lighting is much improved.  

First of all, the flashlight was akin to that of Half-Life 2's flashlight, not a magical spot of light that pastes itself to a wall.

The ambient lighting is actually coming from a light source in this game!  Some rooms look very different with this new lighting.  Most of the time, these rooms were a lot darker than they were in Half-Life.  But this gives a pleasant ambient effect to the game that isn't in the original.  Plus, NPCs have real shadows.

[h1]Source engine physics[/h1]
Unfortunately, due to Valve not wanting to completely redo Half-Life, there's nothing you can pick up and throw.  The boxes still function the same way: You walk into them to push them, and hold "E" to pull them.  But they don't spaz out and fly against a wall when pulling them (which I somewhat missed).

Player physics are literally almost the same as the original.  I can still bunny-hop the way I used to, and I can do Schrodinger's Crouch.  But one thing I found odd is that the jump height is increased.  When in Half-Life, I could jump and zip straight into a pipe, in Half-Life: Source, I smacked my head on the top of the pipe, ruining my perfectly executed move.  While this might not affect average players, those who have a routine for the entire game will likely get screwed up by this.

Ragdolls are also a thing now.  Instead of playing an animation when dying, NPCs drop as ragdolls instead.  I will say that it is pretty satisfying to see a HECU Marine fall dead in his tracks with a right-click of my shotgun.

Source's new water effects have greatly improved sight into the water, but given the rest of the outdated graphics, the better water feels out of place.

[h1]Level design[/h1]
The levels are almost the exact same as those in Half-Life...  [i]Almost[/i].  Valve actually did change a few things.  I noticed that tubes at least in the beginning weren't octogons, and had a higher amount of polygons.  Some terrain was made slighly more realistic, instead of a ramp of sand, there was more of a "bumpy" or "hilly" look to it.  (after 80 hours of trying to speedrun Half-Life, you notice little details like this).  And of course, the canyon scene is very much fixed.  The pipes no longer end spontaneously in an abyss, and the skybox is much improved.  A clear bottom to the canyon can be seen, and you can watch the water ripple.  Other than aesthetic improvements, not much was made to the actual maps.

Enemies, however, I believe have been changed.  Vortigaunts seem to lightning you faster, as if the difficulty was set on "Hard".  I also feel like the HECU Marines do more damage, but maybe they're just a little bit more accurate (or because they actually turn around before you double blast them with the shotgun).  Some HECU vehicles take more hits than they did in Half-Life.  One example would be the HECU chopper that comes in after getting the RPG on the cliffside.  In Half-Life, it usually took one rocket, and it was done.  Now, I used all my rockets (granted I missed half of my shots) and all the Tau Cannon ammo, and it still didn't go down.  The tank after the cliffs also either doesn't take damage from satchel charges beneath it, or takes more than two (satchel charges is how I always dispose of the tank in that level).  Rockets did the trick, though.

[h1]Bug fixes and new bugs found[/h1]
Valve fixed some of my favorite glitches from Half-Life in this game.  The infinite health door is what really hit me hard.  I could no longer beat the game with over 9000 health.  Other fixes include not being able to push buttons through walls (which I missed greatly from my playthrough), and the ability to push friendly NPCs around, so I could skip those talk sequences in the beginning or skip almost the entirety of Office Complex by pushing Barney through a door, or riding the elevator from the outside.

Unfortunately, new bugs have found their way into the game.  Elevators make no sound when you ride them (which isn't terrible, it just ruins the atmosphere).  When I tried to turn on the HD textures pack, few of the weapons would make any sound.  Not my own weapons, not the HECU's weapons, no weapons made any sound.  I switched back and tried to load the save, but it froze and had to restart my Mac.  Started a new game from that chapter (Yes!  You can select a chapter now!) with the HD pack disabled, and it worked fine.  Speaking of textures, the conveyor belt rides in [i]Residue Processing[/i] had a serious problem.  I don't know how to explain it, but be wary of a graphical glitch in that chapter (might be my Mac.  I have no idea).

[h1]Final evaluation: 6/10[/h1]
Half-Life: Source is an attempt at porting a GoldSrc game to the Source engine.  Granted it wasn't a very worthy attempt, but at least it's a start.  If this had been better, I don't think Black Mesa would have existed, and Valve would be raking in all the cash.  But I think the Black Mesa team did a swell job at completely recreating Half-Life, perhaps even better than Valve could've done.  Definitely better than what Valve has actually done.  Sure, I'd recommend it, but only if you need to complete your Half-Life collection.  If you want Half-Life, buy the original.  If you want Half-Life in the Source engine, go for Black Mesa.  Half-Life: Source isn't worth your time.

The only reason I am giving this a reccomendation is because I love half-life. Other than that it's a pretty poorly worked port of half-life to source engine with bugs that honestly make it look like you bought a comedy movie with the game. Go and buy the original version, this version is kinda of broken.

There are two kinds of people who should buy HL: Source. The first is the person who somehow doesn't have a copy of Half-Life but really, really wants Source physics involved. The second is the rabid Half-Life fan who already has Half-Life, Half-Life 2, Half-Life 2 Eps 1 &2, Opposing Force, and Blue Shift and still requires more HL to fill the gaping void Gabe Newell has left in their heart.

I plead no contest.

Seriously, the Source remake didn't really add anything to the game. As near as I can tell, the only gameplay difference is that the crates don't spazz out as much when you try to pull them. Graphically it's mostly the same but the human characters all look significantly creepier. Well, all of them except the G-Man, and he was creepy to begin with.
Has bugs the original Half Life doesn't. Don't bother getting this one. It just looks nicer, but really, it's not worth having the bugs.

If you just want to see Half-Life in the Source engine, then get this game. It doesn't add anything new, just a new engine.
If you want a complete reimangining of Half-Life, get Black Mesa. 

Overall, get this game if you're looking for an excuse to replay Half-Life. It also adds assets to Garry's Mod, if you want that.

Gauss gun thing crashes the game. Also the viewmodels are invisible.

Volvo, plz fix.

It's basically the same thing with prettier water, more comfortable flashlight, faster movement speed and ragdolls instead of original death animations. They fixed Barney's miming of numpad sounds but broke a ton of other things like specific weapon selection sound, gore, Barney's friendly fire, less blood on walls after shooting, the elevator lights are broken, music stopping after loading, echo in vents and larger areas, the subtle head bobbing, the weapons now have recoil and look more oily, the crowbar makes the same sharp sound when hitting stuff, explosions are less satisfying, transparent water, headcrabs don't move around they just stare at you. But on the other hand: crowbar is stronger, swimming is better, flashlight now casts shadows, the textures look crisper and nicer thanks to shaders, FOV is adjustable and higher in weapons, meaning you can see them better. If you want to play HL1 then play HL1, or try Black Mesa, but HL:S is still HL, so play it anyway, to enjoy the few nuances that make the game even better.

The game that rebirthed the FPS genre, launched a torrential downpour of mods from a dedicated fan community and pioneered new storytelling techniques in games. Admittedly, I only finished this game just recently, so without having any sort of nostalgic connection to it, I was not as spellbound by Half-Life as some gamers were when it was new. But I enjoyed myself all the same. It's a game drenched in atmosphere that manages to tell an amazing story with a sense of brevity unmatched by most modern AAA efforts. The dialogue is unintrusive and to the point, and the game focuses more on the environment and atmosphere to tell its story, much like games such as System Shock and Thief. It also manages to balance shooting, exploration and puzzling in a way that never feels stale or drawn-out. All in all, if you still haven't played Half-Life, you owe it to yourself to give it a shot.

While I'll recommend this to anyone, you don't necessarilly need the Source-Engine version to enjoy Half-Life.

Half Life 1 is one of the greatest games of all time. This ports it to the source engine, giving it better graphics and more visual options. 

As if you needed another reason to play as Gordon Freeman until the fabled HL3 comes out?

i highly recommend this game. it is a fun and challenging experience all within a very believable story. there is no story to understand from the beginning, you are the story to be told. some purists say that the original game's graphics engine fits half-life better, but personally, i prefer this engine (although i do not own and have never played the original, i have seen videos and im basing my opinion off of that). if you dont know if the game is worth buying just remember, it's only $10. if you find a way to dislike the game, please see your doctor immediatly.

Very very interesting story line, I love all the half life games and I am a big fan of the immersion into the story line they provide. Here is a list of pros and cons about this game.

Pros:
- Story Line is great
- Easy to follow, but at the same time the game gives you the chance to figure out the situation
- Mechanics work well

Cons:
- Graphics, but that is to be expected from a game of this age.

Nie polecam tej konkretnej wersji half-life'a. Dlaczego? Dlatego, że prawdopodobnie nie będziecie mogli jej przejść. Ostatni boss stał się tu niemożliwy do pokonania za sprawą durnego błędu - cały czas spami teleportami i nie jestem przekonany, czy w ogóle otrzymuje obrażenia, gdy trafimy go w baniak. Nie mogę polecić gry, która nie pozwala się ukończyć.

Natomiast gra jako taka jest na prawdę przyjemna. To pierwszy raz, gdy wziąłem się za grę tego typu i nie żałuję. Bronie są bardzo przyjemne w użyciu, na brak różnorodności absolutnie nie narzekam, wyzwanie jest. Nie jest to co prawda coś na dzisiejsze standardy, ale miło się poznawało grę, którą znać należy : P

The game itself is great, but I don't like this version which is why I don't recommend it.  

They added ragdoll physics and stuff like updated water, but that comes with a lot of annoying bugs and glitches.  

Some better reviewer than me created a detailed list of all the changes from the original, so you can look at that to see if this one is worth a purchase. I bought this with a package so it was worth it in terms of price.  

The game crashed a fair amount and on one level the textures bled everywhere to the point where I couldn't see anything.  I had to search for a fix and it worked but that was really annoying.  Also the skyboxes on some levels are lacking in textures.  I also don't understand why your character moves so freakin' fast.   It's awkward when you're trying to complete the game's numerous jumping puzzles.  

However, this game is a classic that has influenced numerous subsequent FPSes, so if you buy this game you're owning a piece of gaming history.  I just think you should try to get the original version if you can, though Black Mesa looks interesting, too.  

Update:  I played HL2 again recently.  I changed my mind about HL1 not standing the test of time as much as the sequel.  The more complex levels that you find in older shooters remain fun to play, and though I love HL2 its linearity makes multiple playthroughs less appealing.  However, some of the levels in HL2 are extremely well-designed and I'll always enjoy them.
